abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Nearly half of all human proteins are acetylated at their N-termini by the NatA N-terminal acetyltransferase complex. NAA10 is evolutionarily conserved as the catalytic subunit of NatA in complex with NAA15, but may also have NatA-independent functions. Several <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variants are associated with genetic disorders. The phenotypic spectrum includes developmental delay, intellectual disability, and cardiac abnormalities. Here, we have identified the previously undescribed <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> c.303C>A and c.303C>G p.(N101K) variants in two unrelated girls. These girls have developmental delay, but they both also display hemihypertrophy a feature normally not observed or registered among these cases. Functional studies revealed that <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> p.(N101K) is completely impaired in its ability to bind NAA15 and to form an enzymatically active NatA complex. In contrast, the integrity of <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> p.(N101K) as a monomeric acetyltransferase is intact. Thus, this <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variant may represent the best example of the impact of NatA mediated N-terminal acetylation, isolated from other potential NAA10-mediated cellular functions and may provide important insights into the phenotypes observed in individuals expressing pathogenic <jats:italic>NAA10</jats:italic> variants.</jats:p>
